awd_titl_txt: EAGER: An Accessible Coding Curriculum for Engaging Underserved Students with Special Needs in Afterschool Programs
awd_abstract_narration:
Many schools are trying to figure out how to comply with new computing directives, especially given there are a limited number of trained teachers that are comfortable with this new subject area. State and federal mandates, on the other hand, also require supporting the learning requirements of students with special needs. The scarcity of accessible interfaces for learning computing can lead to students with disabilities not having equal access in these new initiatives. In addition, most schools in low socioeconomic communities are often under-resourced, creating a further divide and challenge in bringing computer science training directly into the classroom environment. This work will investigate methods to positively impact underserved students with special needs by ensuring equal access to computer science curriculum, with a focus on 1) designing an accessible coding curriculum to engage underserved students with special needs in hands-on computing education in the afterschool space and 2) through pilot studies evaluate the learning outcomes for two ethnically diverse populations of middle school students with special needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
There are 1 billion disabled people on this planet, yet there is a shortage of accessible learning materials and resources for them. The Americans with Disabilities(ADA) has made great progress in making physical spaces more accessible for people with disabilities, but as we transform into a more digitalized world, further guidance and accessibility of digital resources, especially those of learning materials is required. The latter is especially important as online learning becomes prevalent in a post COVID-19 pandemic world. Of special interest to us, is accessibility of computer science curriculums and learning tools. According to the US Bureau of Labor Statistics, the employment of computer and information research scientists is projected to grow 15 percent from 2019 to 2029. However, individuals with disabilities are less likely to pursue information technology degrees. This is mainly due to the inaccessibility or partial accessibility of learning materials and software used for programming. Additionally, coding programs and workshops for K-12 students are immensely popular, but many tools used to teach in these programs, such as block-based programming, are not accessible to people with disabilities. Our research was divided into four major parts:

  1. Conduct literature review and user research to identify accessibility gaps in K-12 computer programming tools, specifically block-based programming.
  2. Build an accessible solution for major affected disabled audiences, such as those who are Blind/Low Vision(BLV), Deaf/Hard of Hearing(D/HH), and those with motor disabilities.
  3. Conduct user testing with some of the targeted population above.
  4. Amending the solution based on user feedback and integrating these accessible tools with an accessible curriculum.

 

The following are the demos of the end-products of our work:

●      A voice based accessible solution for BLV students to learn block-based programming.

○      Screen-reader solution: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QuumG0n3K2M&t=3s

○      Custom Voice solution using Text to Speech:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vlPxnPPrz9o&t=4s

●      A voice based accessible solution for motorically disabled students to learn block-based programming.

○      Speech-to-Text solution:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cifI1w1Ggl8&t=1s

○      Improved Speech-to-Text using Natural Language Processing:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ikU6DQSMxGU

●      Creation of American Sign Language(ASL) video content for D/HH students to learn computer science concepts:

○      Example of ‘Introduction to Computer Science’ video in ASL: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kznnvG19Udo

○      A tooltip of ASL for every coding block - which provides more information on what the block does:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0CV5herpHsU

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2021
Modified by: Mahender A Mandala
